title: High School - English I for Speakers of Other Languages
subject: Spanish Language Arts and Reading (2017-)

document.title: TEXAS ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS FOR SPANISH LANGUAGE ARTS AND READING AND ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE

DEFCC1938A9C429BB5B8DA4B666F1CB3.description: use an appropriate mode of delivery, whether written, oral, pictorial, or multimodal, to present results.

19052714EF964381BD99727F6EBF51ED.description: incorporate digital technology when appropriate; and

CE916E6B01A1474589A385EC3229CCE4.description: display academic citations, including for paraphrased and quoted text, and use source materials ethically to avoid plagiarism;

A005CED1BEE04CF79D53B715A4BDFE87.description: faulty reasoning such as ad hominem, loaded language, and slippery slope;

84C6DC67D8994946B7F4D1D975A6C48E.description: credibility and bias, including omission; and

AE071F53427A492A82B7D262C20FD085.description: synthesize information from a variety of sources;

6F034890CDD7488C9EA1F694E2945B30.description: modify the major research question as necessary to refocus the research plan;

195ECA9212FE40B2BD7312F3294182AF.description: critique the research process at each step to implement changes as needs occur and are identified;

AC0354D2BB6140E99332B12630488B33.description: develop questions for formal and informal inquiry;

9D4F22A8A1FF4F0D97B7B79BCFFC8303.description: Inquiry and research: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student engages in both short-term and sustained recursive inquiry processes for a variety of purposes. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

DE83D9C3BB954FC099FD3D9A08426290.description: compose correspondence in a professional or friendly structure.

E1612C4CA5B646ACAD4CB4C43CAE8BB2.description: compose argumentative texts using genre characteristics and craft; and

B3082868B7404889A7393860A8CB842F.description: compose informational texts such as explanatory essays, reports, and personal essays using genre characteristics and craft;

6179A7C574E0438597C0A1F8F707CBE9.description: compose literary texts such as fiction and poetry using genre characteristics and craft;

8879323072094E4788F8BB54855EC0F5.description: Composition: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--genres. The student uses genre characteristics and craft to compose multiple texts that are meaningful. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

D11B1C99FF2D49ECAC1F3CFDC7A6910B.description: publish written work for appropriate audiences.

29A0BA2685014D18B762AC6B349C0416.description: use sentence-combining techniques to create a variety of sentence structures and lengths;

F5B152A94E8A4345986A0D5DE34CB5A9.description: punctuation, including commas, semicolons, colons, and dashes to set off phrases and clauses as appropriate; and

7ED26D6978A84CDFA7B05C13D3A91C49.description: consistent, appropriate use of verb tense and active and passive voice;

8793C33B83F24187AB6368C4EEEEA583.description: a variety of complete, controlled sentences and avoidance of unintentional splices, run-ons, and fragments;

B9431CDF9B164750A6BF5F493D405882.description: edit drafts using standard English conventions, including:

4770163A51C5408686E36B27CBC6380A.description: revise drafts to improve clarity, development, organization, style, diction, and sentence effectiveness, including use of parallel constructions and placement of phrases and dependent clauses;

880A6026B75046D9B4E129D431BA1410.description: developing an engaging idea reflecting depth of thought with specific details, examples, and commentary;

08B4F08FC9C4449CA10FA4CDCA87B3A3.description: using an organizing structure appropriate to purpose, audience, topic, and context; and

D76925B96E7247F2A0C33F865BC09B5A.description: develop drafts into a focused, structured, and coherent piece of writing in timed and open-ended situations by:

B7C2BB7A2C154F4B98394891656BC3AE.description: plan a piece of writing appropriate for various purposes and audiences by generating ideas through a range of strategies such as brainstorming, journaling, reading, or discussing;

A07A7FE48AFF45FC8B9C2E3D2BF7BD92.description: Composition: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--writing process. The student uses the writing process recursively to compose multiple texts that are legible and use appropriate conventions. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

F5F1DC10B35249F5821C272C12D976AC.description: identify and explain the purpose of rhetorical devices such as understatement and overstatement and the effect of logical fallacies such as straw man and red herring arguments.

6C6E141F918140FBAF1E37A003D53EC9.description: identify and analyze the use of rhetorical devices, including allusion, repetition, appeals, and rhetorical questions; and

15A2474F00D34DF99A9A051B4AE6747D.description: identify and analyze how the author's diction and syntax contribute to the mood, voice, and tone of a text;

62991B2B300747C99C752D101A84F1ED.description: identify and analyze the use of literary devices such as irony and oxymoron to achieve specific purposes;

0735D07D35484B48B18F92A8E36D590B.description: identify and analyze how the author's use of language achieves specific purposes;

75550DC6F1EA4F55AD76117493DC109F.description: identify and evaluate the author's use of print and graphic features to achieve specific purposes;

38AA099C553243EDBA37C007F1502CA8.description: identify and analyze use of text structure to achieve the author's purpose;

BBC78E67DB094F54BA495968B9EFD85B.description: identify and analyze the author's purpose, audience, and message within a text;

5E8F18BB2403418C88F80633DAFDCEE3.description: Author's purpose and craft: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student uses critical inquiry to analyze the authors' choices and how they influence and communicate meaning within a variety of texts. The student analyzes and applies author's craft purposefully in order to develop his or her own products and performances. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

033C15993BF247C1B443886395D20E7F.description: identify and analyze characteristics of multimodal and digital texts.

4A7C7E3B79AA4E20A68D233D288B7000.description: various types of evidence and treatment of counterarguments, including concessions and rebuttals; and

D6C0DC4FAA594788B2189AF0BB42716D.description: clear arguable claim, appeals, and convincing conclusion;

959E143D2DB3434994E682E90B5E3F7B.description: identify and analyze characteristics and structural elements of argumentative texts such as:

A662B9EE763B4F3587D6C8DDD6F49775.description: multiple organizational patterns within a text to develop the thesis;

F107D5FCB2A94BEBA1DDAFDE13600D87.description: chapters, sections, subsections, bibliography, tables, graphs, captions, bullets, and numbers; and

BFCC96AF36C249A5A4BBE967A513A687.description: controlling idea and clear thesis, relevant supporting evidence, pertinent examples, and conclusion;

3C2245E79E8F4BB5AD1724C8FFA2F01E.description: identify and analyze characteristics and structural elements of informational texts such as:

A40F79A6249145729BD1C0AAA04D4C45.description: identify and analyze the function of dramatic conventions such as asides, soliloquies, dramatic irony, and satire;

96F5793195474596AB92A1C816C84A4D.description: identify and analyze the structure, prosody, and graphic elements such as line length and word position in poems across a variety of poetic forms;

BD5795DACAC14D22B2822E94DB8B2522.description: read and respond to American, British, and world literature;

2DEEB3BC1E7B47F18D200F82C72A1C10.description: Multiple genres: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--genres. The student recognizes and analyzes genre-specific characteristics, structures, and purposes within and across increasingly complex traditional, contemporary, classical, and diverse texts. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

145BC59004FF46EDAFB6BE98AA499FE1.description: identify and analyze how the setting influences the theme.

AC3470C0C8E6426BA89A4BE85A8D1ABF.description: identify and analyze non-linear plot development such as flashbacks, foreshadowing, subplots, and parallel plot structures and compare it to linear plot development; and

66C80F87053A4B47B5E7233B5388C875.description: identify and analyze how authors develop complex yet believable characters in works of fiction through a range of literary devices, including character foils;

0D92C92CB4184ADE94A24CFCC057DE2E.description: identify and analyze how themes are developed through characterization and plot in a variety of literary texts;

FB08D15F7AB6413FAF207AC87124B634.description: Multiple genres: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--literary elements. The student recognizes and analyzes literary elements within and across increasingly complex traditional, contemporary, classical, and diverse literary texts. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

BF228608F1AF435F82540401E46D9551.description: express opinions, ideas, and feelings ranging from communicating single words and short phrases to participating in extended discussions.

BA28D80898B244E797AF46E7B51888C7.description: defend or challenge the authors' claims using relevant text evidence; and

97446EBEF0E94986BF0B71A15EBDDF09.description: reflect on and adjust responses when valid evidence warrants;

04D4973731C341DB89A0BF47F45611C4.description: respond orally or in writing with appropriate register, vocabulary, tone, and voice;

76D1D9BB930941DEAB3A179984111EFE.description: discuss and write about the explicit or implicit meanings of text;

5A451F43762947DABA0E17496224B180.description: respond using acquired content and academic vocabulary as appropriate;

ED3EE89B3CCE48E2A5CF63E48F540175.description: interact with sources in meaningful ways such as labeling, notetaking, annotating, freewriting, or illustrating;

D57F06A075BB4CE48E70C394335815CB.description: paraphrase and summarize texts in ways that maintain meaning and logical order;

38B8DE5FE0784927B52B7ECE8AA04F83.description: use text evidence and original commentary to support a comprehensive response;

3D324BB4B03B4685B67D1AD44128E5F9.description: write responses that demonstrate understanding of texts, including comparing texts within and across genres;

3047DEBCBA964A089DA30912657B8679.description: describe personal connections to a variety of sources, including self-selected texts;

1521B605A853424983A2D10C4470629E.description: Response skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student responds to an increasingly challenging variety of sources that are read, heard, or viewed. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

924A2CC03E1C434F8C26AE1A54AAF1B7.description: monitor comprehension and make adjustments such as re-reading, using background knowledge, asking questions, and annotating when understanding breaks down.

237F0A35029B45239263A2DDD673501D.description: synthesize information from two texts to create new understanding; and

CD95A7E2C1EC4357A28C73C3CAC34B80.description: actively participate in discussions to identify, understand, and evaluate details read to determine key ideas;

916F0AFF4B174F1DBD209EACD76AC35A.description: make inferences and use evidence to support understanding;

930DE9538DBA429FAF5C704C24F4EF64.description: make connections to personal experiences, ideas in other texts, and society;

F85E8E761E7841D2971DE8BC1EA2D253.description: create mental images to deepen understanding;

13C71F7957034D4A931AA5EAB6DCA72F.description: make and correct or confirm predictions using text features, characteristics of genre, and structures;

4549BFADE1194944928B306B16660B7A.description: answer and generate questions about text before, during, and after reading to acquire and deepen understanding and gain information;

68CD6DFD64F04E11B7AAEF46849F8C80.description: establish purpose for reading assigned and self-selected texts;

4F331B458AA2405FAE45FC331AED584C.description: Comprehension skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student uses metacognitive skills to both develop and comprehend increasingly complex texts. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

D44C55B4BD8041698DAFE5939CEF07B1.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--self-sustained reading. The student reads grade- and language proficiency-appropriate texts with increasing independence. The student is expected to self-select text and read independently for a sustained period of time.

23D1D4550BF946C48303639AD9EF451A.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--fluency. The student reads grade-level text with fluency and comprehension. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to adjust fluency when reading grade-level and language proficiency-level text based on the reading purpose.

A356B0BB7B1548F5A54F80FA1A6CF34D.description: investigate expressions such as idioms and word relationships such as antonyms, synonyms, and analogies.

84D3D17FADFD4251B6522BFBAEF80B70.description: identify, understand, and use multiple-meaning words, homographs, homophones, and commonly confused terms correctly; and

A654C374A1514591844229A679F2D27A.description: identify and use words that name actions, directions, positions, sequences, and locations;

97EAD7AC32004CE9A89016DF2E8BF944.description: determine the meaning of foreign words or phrases used frequently in English such as bona fide, caveat, carte blanche, tête-à-tête, bon appétit, and quid pro quo;

5B0F02AC0C21409AB13EEAE9B0A876EA.description: discuss and analyze context and use cognates to distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words and phrases;

3F2F0F734DE84FCD858DCA5974226624.description: use print or digital resources such as glossaries or technical dictionaries to clarify and validate understanding of the precise and appropriate meaning of technical or discipline-based vocabulary;

833C9862719C402195A8997425510D55.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--vocabulary. The student uses newly acquired vocabulary expressively. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

95387A0C02FD448EA6DA1ED1731CAE00.description: write complete words, thoughts, and answers legibly.

6A92C7E5D49340E299EDAE321B39AA91.description: acquire, demonstrate, and apply phonetic knowledge; and

62397D60609642D9AC4A3C22202F3812.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--beginning reading and writing. The student develops word structure knowledge through phonological awareness, print concepts, phonics, and morphology to communicate, decode, and spell. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:

819D7C38FD5C4615BCB5BFF80E4B63EF.description: conduct an interview, including social and informative.

412795B25358438E89B8AAE1FFC586F6.description: develop social communication and produce oral language in contextualized and purposeful ways; and

5429601F59094C49B7AD5769D628D2A7.description: participate collaboratively, building on the ideas of others, contributing relevant information, developing a plan for consensus building, and setting ground rules for decision making;

B55072822BB84EC58ADB727B43B7C17F.description: give a presentation using informal, formal, and technical language effectively to meet the needs of audience, purpose, and occasion, employing eye contact, speaking rate such as pauses for effect, volume, enunciation, purposeful gestures, and increasing mastery of conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively;

8DA6AB8DC3A5445FA15B809EA23FB12F.description: follow, restate, and give complex oral instructions to perform specific tasks, answer questions, or solve problems and complex processes;

BB0D469A16DA47BFBE46D521EB088ADF.description: share prior knowledge with peers and others to facilitate communication;

B77705D6A0964D0080F44B53C69531FE.description: engage in meaningful and respectful discourse by listening actively, responding appropriately, and adjusting communication to audiences and purposes;

F211A385FAC64CA9BD0DFA950FF131AE.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, discussion, and thinking--oral language. The student develops oral language through listening, speaking, and discussion. Based on the student's language proficiency level, and with appropriately provided English language development scaffolding, the student is expected to:
